review:
Distant Space is a game, that feels somewhat like Space Invaders.

Survive hordes of enemies in your trusty ship as you avoid their projectiles whilst destroying them with your projectiles. There aren't many powerups in this game but there doesn't need to be, that being double and triple blasters, each shooting, well, double and triple your original projectile count. 

There won't be just regular enemies standing in your way, there will also be tanky bosses that are no joke, only possible with the help of your quick reflexes and accuracy.

The one thing I'd add is 4 more levels, 26 is only used to make it so the achievements can be represented by the letters of the alphabet. 30 is a more round number and more fitting overall. Even though the shield and two powerups are good on their own, I'd maybe include something like a homing missile powerup with slower attack speed but the ability to home, like the enemies in the game use.

Still though, Distant Space is great and I will be playing the sequel in the near future, and you should too!

review:
Distant Space is a 2D retro pixel Galaga (1981) ripoff that's been slapped together with the godawful GameMaker Studio video game construction kit from Yoyogames.   It's a very basic fixed shooter where you push your fighter along the bottom of your screen and shoot waves of enemies as they flow onto the screen.   The game features ultra-lazy, no effort 2D retro pixel "line art", and looks terrible as a result.

GameMaker Studio is a very poor quality game construction kit, and unsurprisingly results in products that have little to no value as games, especially when compared to the work of professional developers who create genuine products for gamers.  Using a video game construction kit requires little to no talent or skill as a game developer.  Very often, GameMaker Studio is used to make shovelware and lazy cash grabs. 

Like most GameMaker Studio construction kit "games", this features lazy 2D retro pixel/line "art", instead of professionally done, contemporary PC graphics.  Controls and resolution are locked, which pushes this below acceptable standards for PC. 

Don't take my word on this shovelware being untouchable... there's an achievement for just starting the game, and only 5% of the people who own the game bothered to install and launch it.  Ouch.

Distant Space a retro space invader type game.

Simple game all you need to do is complete each level and a couple of boss levels by killing all enemies.

They go around the screen in a pattern (sort of like Space Invaders but with more patterns) you just need to stay ahead of them while fireing.

The graphics are alright in a retro way but I did turn the music off and put my own on.

If you collect the drops from the kills you do get a second weapon upgrade which I did not realise till near the end which can give you limited double or even triple shots at the enemy.

The enemy have a few different weapon types like missles, one shot and splitter shots.

Pretty short game to be honest tho did it all within a few minutes (rest of time played is waiting for card drops)

Easy game for 100% and achievements. 

The achievements are quite nice for an achievement showcase as well.

Steam badges as well.

I would recommend this game at a low low price or on sale.

It's a good. Albeit a bit more on the short side you can easily use it for farming achievements and cards. I didn't regret buying it, although I have seen all the the game can offer within half an hour.

What is maybe to mention is, that it ran with a minor but constant lag, though that could have had to do with the heavy harddisk surveilance job I was running in the background. The game however managed to fill the wait well and kept me interested as long as it lasted.

The graphics could be right out of an early 80's vector based Atari Arcade machine or a Vectrex with the improvement of a nice interference effect all over the place so it should appeal to all you retro gamers out there, while the fairly short chiptune together with the somewhat flat sound effects does suit the overall style of the game perfectly well.

Buy it on sale when you've got half an hour to waste, but beware: it uses mouse controls accompanied by some minor keyboard inputs for ship movement and other things that cannot be changed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140601805', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 734, 'last_played': 1515291663}
review:
Oh wow they literally removed the entire game and made a new one. Well, I'm changing my review to reflect my actual opinion on this new game, compared to the one they made before. 

It has similar mechanics, and a lot of improvements, compared to its previous state. The game is still hard, but not to the point where it becomes annoying like before, it is actually fun to keep playing now. The new song they put is far less repetitive and more enjoyable than the previous one, which they used now for the menu screen. You now have more health points, a shield, power-ups (which you can save for later, not like before, where you used them instantly), and you don't have to start from the beginning when you die (you now start on the same level). This last change is REALLY important. This was the aspect that put me off when playing the previous game. Before, you had only 3 hits in the entire game, and if you died on any level, you had to start from the beginning. That was a huge annoyance for those who wanted to get all the achievements for beating the game, so I'm glad they improved on that aspect. Lastly, you control the ship with the mouse now, not with the arrow keys, so it is far easier to dodge projectiles and stuff.

My only real complaints now is that you have to click to shoot, when I prefer to use a key. Also, I prefered the artstyle of the previous game, but whatever.

I'd say this game is worth the money, if you want about an hour of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971341065', 'num_games_owned': 3377, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 2534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2534, 'last_played': 1509562454}
review:
Distant Space (was Space Distant, but the game is massively changed since a patch that changed the name) is a fairly basic Space Invaders variant with little to recommend it, you will take on about 23 waves of very similar groups of aliens firing down at you, and at certain points fight three boss aliens.

The game is very easy, you can take a fair few hits each level, so progress is almost inevitable no matter how bad you are at these games, and when you die you will get back full health and shield, and even keep any special ammo you still have in store, so the only real penalty is having to start clearing the level from the start again. The only even slightly tough level is the final one, and even that I cleared first time (well I deliberately died once to refresh my health, so I guess technically second time)

The aliens are all similar monochrome outlines, and the bosses are just larger monochrome outlines, and pretty much every regular level plays out the same apart from the aliens follow different paths around the screen, but you just slide from side to side firing all the time without really aiming until there are only a couple left. Although the aliens have a few different variants that shoot differently, and a couple more are added into the mix as levels advance, it all feels very samey.

As mentioned there are a couple of weapon power ups you use with the right mouse button, but these are simply a double and triple fire, which are useful for quickly clearing the bulk of the aliens at the start of a level, and it is a nice change from the previous versions that you can choose to use them when you choose, but not exactly very interesting or gameplay changing.

The boss fights are fairly easy generally but long winded and tedious as every time you hit the boss it flashes with immunity for half a second or so, so you have to slowly wear them down, but as mentioned this isn't very hard to do.

Overall there is really nothing I can think of to recommend this game at this point, previous versions weren't great but at least posed a challenge that I kept coming back to try to beat every now and then, even if I should have probably spent the time playing better games, now it doesn't even have that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996890045', 'num_games_owned': 3060, 'num_reviews': 293, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1482281799}
review:
Distant Space is a retro-styled version of Space Invaders.
There's not a lot to it - just the usual case of shoot down the aliens before they get you.

Some of the bigger aliens take more than one shot to kill.
Several aliens shoot diagonally.
The first boss is massive and has heat-seeking missiles
(Apparently there is a second boss - at level 15? - but I haven't got that far yet.)

Although Space Distant doesn't specify what controls the game uses, after having spent thousands of dollars on exhaustive research and private investigators, I can now reveal that they are:
Spacebar = shoot
Arrow keys = move left and right

This game is not one you would want to play over and over again.
But, then again, it has achievements, so you might want to play it a few times to get those. 

It's a cheap game, just under a dollar, so you can't go too wrong with it - however, considering how basic it is, I would have thought that 50 cents would be more reasonable.

For a cheap game it's ok, but nothing more than that.
